segments.text: The weather's changing. I can see clouds building to the west. Not what the forecast said.
Let me check the barometer on my watch... pressure's dropping. Down 8 millibars in the last two hours.
That's significant. Could mean a storm moving in faster than predicted.
I'm going to head back to camp now. I'm about an hour away, should make it before conditions deteriorate.
When I get there, I need to secure everything. Extra guy lines on the tent, move gear inside, make sure the bear canister is locked down.
The wind's already picking up. I can feel it gusting from the west.
This is why you always watch the weather in the mountains. Forecasts are predictions, not guarantees.
I'm not worried exactly, but I'm being smart. If this turns into a real storm, I want to be prepared.
My tent's rated for high winds and snow load. I've got food and water for a week if I need to wait it out.
The satellite communicator is charged. I can call for help if things get bad, though I don't expect that.
Biggest risk is being stuck in the tent for a day or two. Boring, but not dangerous.
I brought books for exactly this scenario. And my journal. Plenty of ways to pass time.
Temperature's dropping too. Feels like it's already down to minus 5 or so.
Alright, picking up the pace. I want to be at camp in 45 minutes. No point taking unnecessary risks.
This is part of wilderness camping. Mother Nature doesn't care about your plans. You adapt or you suffer.

environment.background_sounds: increasing wind, boots on rocky trail, fabric rustling
